Chapter 9: Distinguishing Dependent Origination, part 3, section 9. Having explained ignorance, we will now explain name-and-form.
Form has already been explained, but what is name?
Verse:
Name refers to the four formless aggregates.
Discussion:
The Buddha said that the four formless aggregates are called name.
Why is it called name?
Because it can express and summon, that is, it can express and summon various objects.
If that is so, it should not completely include the formless and non-associated dharmas, because they have no objects.
It is not so. Expressing and summoning only exists in the formless realm, just as explaining the name form, without any error.

The Buddha said that because it obstructs and changes, it is called form. Although past and future unmanifest form and subtle particles have no obstruction and change, they can be called form, because in the formless realm there is no obstruction and change.
The name form that obstructs and changes is not completely established.

Thus, in the formless realm, there may be intimation, because there is no form there. This is also reasonable and not contradictory. Therefore, there is no error in including non-associated [phenomena] in name.
Moreover, because it is subtle, it is given a name according to the principle in each case, and is designated as name.
Non-intimation, etc. can also be called name, because their basis is apprehended by direct perception.
Moreover, it is able to universally seek in all realms, stages, destinies, and births, and therefore it is established as name.
Non-outflows and formless [dharmas] cannot be called name, although they are not what is being discussed here, they are similar to this.
Moreover, in the formless realm, it is said in general according to the feelings of the speaker, and there is no need to question it.
The elder's idea is that it is called name because it conforms to and establishes the continuity of each sentient being, and it is able to be the cause, conforming to that meaning.
If so, then form dharmas should also be called name, because they are also able to be the cause and conform to that.
The Buddha said that earth, etc. establish the bodies of sentient beings, because the sutra says that the person is precisely the six elements.

Moreover, there is no scripture that says only the formless aggregates constitute the body of sentient beings. However, there is a scripture that says the continuity of sentient beings is caused by form, etc. Therefore, their explanation of the name has no basis.
Isn't it that the Buddha said this verse:
Name can overshadow everything, there is nothing that surpasses name;
Therefore, in the one dharma of name, all follow its sovereign functioning.
What does this citation prove?
Does the verse show that the continuity of sentient beings is only accomplished by formless dharmas?
Or does it show that formless [dharmas] strongly attract form, and that formless [dharmas] are the accomplishing cause in the continuity of sentient beings?

If it is said that all the continuities of sentient beings are not accomplished by formless [dharmas], this is also unreasonable, because for those without mind, only form accomplishes the continuity.
It has already been established that sentient beings without mind do not have attainment, etc. as their accomplishing cause.
Moreover, each sentient being has the aggregates of the three realms as a single continuum, so the various material dharmas are also the causes of the continua of all sentient beings.
Otherwise, one would either obtain without making or lose after making, which would be an overextension.
If the material dharmas of the various states of the continua of one sentient being were not universal, then the formless realm would be the same.

Moreover, one should carefully consider the meaning of this verse: does it say that the four aggregates such as feeling are called name, or does it say that that which can express the meanings of specific characteristics is called name?

It is like the term color of an ox, which is based on name and called name. However, in this case, it should only say that which can express the names of all material and immaterial dharmas is called name. Only this has the power to surpass all dharmas, because there is not a single dharma that is not expressed by name. Apart from this, what name can surpass all?
Moreover, the twelve sense bases are called all dharmas. How can feeling, etc. surpass the twelve sense bases?
If it is said that they are all the objects of feeling, etc., then the name in this case only refers to mental consciousness and its associated dharmas.

If you say that the other dharmas are called name because they are similar to it, then the error is not committed. But then you should not quote this verse as proof that name is the cause of the continuity of sentient beings. If only mental consciousness and its associated dharmas are called name in this verse, then you should not quote it as proof that name is the cause, because the five consciousnesses and their associated dharmas are also causes that assist in the continuity of sentient beings.

Also, how can you say that name is without error? If you say that many aggregates are established in name, and form is not so, then many elements and bases are established in form, so how can name be superior?
If you say that name is common to the formless realms, then those dharmas that are not common should not be called name.
If you say that those that are not common are a kind of common dharma, and therefore there is no error, this is not so, because previously it was said that this verse should not be quoted as proof.

It is also a cause for the continuity of sentient beings who are not yet liberated, because it is the same as those who are liberated. Apart from the name that is grasped, what other dharma can be said to follow the activity of the sovereign?
If it is said that this name and form follow the activity, that is also unreasonable, because it is not established.
It is said that name and form rely on each other. How can it only be said that form follows the transformation of name?
If it is said that name pervades form, but form cannot pervade name, that is also unreasonable, because non-sentient beings do not exist.
Moreover, it has already been said that there are sentient beings without mind.
Also, there is no dharma outside of name and form that follows the transformation of name. The sÅ«tra says that the known dharmas are generally two: name and form, and there is no third.
Moreover, it is unreasonable for the four aggregates to be called one.
Even if it is allowed that the word one dharma refers to form, we do not see any definite accompanying dharma.
The essence cannot follow the essence, therefore we know that this name only expresses thought.
If we interpret it in this way, there is no need to expend effort in explaining this verse, as the meaning becomes clear.
To cite it as evidence that the four aggregates are called name and constitute the sentient body is definitely unreasonable.
The Sthavira raises a hypothetical objection:

If the term name-and-form comprehensively includes the five aggregates, since the World-Honored One says that consciousness depends on name-and-form, then consciousness would have two aspects: the dependent and the basis of dependence.
He himself explains:
This objection is unreasonable, because consciousness has already been brought up in the middle of the term name.
That is to say, consciousness has already been brought up as the dependent, so it is understood that the basis of consciousness's dependence only takes the remaining name-and-form.
Now, examining his objection, the principle is not established by itself, because the immediately preceding condition definitely depends on consciousness.
However, the Sthavira does not allow that consciousness and name-and-form simultaneously have the principle of mutual dependence, because his school does not allow for simultaneous cause and effect.
How can it be that because consciousness does not arise simultaneously in two [aspects], it is then said that consciousness does not have the meaning of depending on consciousness again?

Also, even if you admit that consciousness and the other four are mutually supported, consciousness can be the support of feeling, etc., but feeling, etc., cannot be the support of consciousness. How can the support of consciousness be called name-and-form?
Therefore the questions and answers of the opponent are unreasonable.

We must now consider the meaning of the Buddhaâ€™s statement in the MahÄyÄna MahÄpari nirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, the Parable of the City, that consciousness and name-and-form are conditions for each other. Does this refer to a sequential relation or to a simultaneous relation?
Consciousness as a condition for name-and-form refers to a sequential relation, but name-and-form as a condition for consciousness refers only to a simultaneous relation.
Why is this?
Because consciousness enters the motherâ€™s womb and combines with the kalala, forming the body of a sentient being, therefore consciousness as a condition for name-and-form can be sequential.
But once name-and-form combine, they do not form another consciousness, and if consciousness has not yet arisen, name-and-form are not its condition. Therefore the relation is only simultaneous.
There is a name-and-form as a condition for consciousness, because the member of consciousness is only one.

Also, because they are in the same moment. That is, in the twelve members of conditioned arising, only one member, consciousness, is said to be in the same moment. How can you insist that consciousness and name-and-form are definitely said to be in different time periods and to be conditions for each other?
Also, a scripture says,
Because they are like bundles of reeds.
A scripture says,
Two bundles of reeds stand leaning against each other.
When one falls down, the other falls.
In the same way, good man,
two things support each other: consciousness conditions name-and-form, and name-and-form conditions consciousness.
If you reject the idea that they are conditions for each other in the same moment, how can you be like the bundles of reeds?
That is, when consciousness exists, name-and-form does not yet exist.

When name-and-form exists, consciousness has already ceased. There is definitely no meaning of mutual support like that of the bundles of reeds. How much less is there a meaning of mutual support like that of the bundles of reeds when you deny that past and future exist?
Because one exists at one time and the other does not exist at that time.

There is no mutual dependence between nonexistence and existence, or between existence and nonexistence, but there is mutual dependence between existence and existence. Therefore, those who maintain that the characteristics are definitely sequential are outside the teachings of the sages and not the school of Buddhism.
Moreover, a scripture says:
Ignorance and attention arise simultaneously and are conditions for each other.
It is said that ignorance is the cause of improper attention, and improper attention arises from delusion. It is also said that these two arise simultaneously.
Therefore, a scripture says:
The eye and form as conditions give rise to defiled and turbid attention born of delusion.
Here, delusion refers to ignorance, and so on at length.
The phrase here in the text indicates that when attention arises, or when the conditions that are indicated come together,
the two dharmas that belong to the same conditions cannot arise sequentially, because when the two arise simultaneously there is no obstruction.

Also, light and a lamp arise simultaneously, and there is a relation of cause and effect between them. This has already been discussed in the section on the simultaneous cause. Thus the simultaneous arising of cause and effect is well established.
However, there is a defense:
Light is not different from a lamp.
This is unreasonable, because the two have different functions, light being the form aggregate and a lamp being the aggregate of contact.
The world speaks only of flame as a lamp, just as it says that light is a lamp and that a lamp burns things.
The scriptures say:
Light depends on a lamp, just as the light of the sun and moon depends on the sun and moon to arise.
Also, the great earth depends on the water wheel, and water and earth arise together, only then can there be a relation of support.
The difference in kind between light and a lamp is well established, and the meaning of the simultaneous arising of cause and effect is made clear in this case.
Although light arises depending on its own primary elements, when it arises it is not separate from the flame of a lamp.
If it is said that light and flame arise from the same cause, because the cause of flame is the cause of light, this is also unreasonable, because there is a difference.
It is not that a single combination produces a single effect, nor that a single effect is produced by a single combination. How is it that the sound of striking fire occurs simultaneously?
How can it be that a single combination produces a single effect?
This is not so, because they are based on separate things, and because causes of the same species each produce their own effects.
Therefore the opponent's rescue is mere empty talk. Thus the lamp and light are different in substance.
If consciousness and name-and-form are conditions for each other, why does the scripture say that consciousness is the condition for name-and-form and vice versa?
Although this principle is comprehensive, it shows that the function of consciousness is strong, and therefore it is said in a one-sided way.

The function of consciousness is strong because consciousness is the support for feeling, conceptualization, volition, and mind, and it evolves using them as supports. Because consciousness holds semen and blood and forms the kalala, forming the body of sentient beings, its function is superior.
Just as a king and his ministers, although mutually supporting, the king is given the name because he is most excellent;
so it is with consciousness and name-and-form. This should be understood in the same way.
Also, when it is said that consciousness conditions name-and-form, it refers to the condition of prior birth;

when it is said that they serve as conditions for each other, it refers only to their simultaneous arising, because the condition of consciousness for name-and-form extends to prior, subsequent, and simultaneous states, while the condition of name-and-form for consciousness exists only in the simultaneous state, because the consciousness of rebirth does not have a separate state.
Also, when it is said that consciousness conditions name-and-form, it refers to name-and-form in a state of development;
when it is said that they serve as conditions for each other, it refers to name-and-form in a single moment.
The Venerable RÄma, following his own ideas, says:

When one is reborn from the intermediate state, at the time of rebirth the name-and-form of the intermediate state serves as a condition and immediately produces the consciousness of the class of rebirth.
The name-and-form of the intermediate state ceases, and only consciousness is born. This is able to produce the name-and-form of birth.

This kind of investigation is not in accord with correct principles. When it is said that the name-and-form of the intermediate state serves as a condition and immediately produces the consciousness of the class of rebirth, is it that the consciousness of the intermediate state is also able to serve as a condition, or is it only the other name-and-form except for the consciousness of the intermediate state?

If the consciousness of the intermediate state is also a condition, what principle is there that the last moment of mind and its activities and form in the intermediate state are conditions, but mind alone is attracted and born and not mind and form?
If you say that the exception is made for consciousness and the rest are conditions, what principle is there that consciousness born with the others is not a condition?

If you say that at that time there is no consciousness born with the others, then the consciousness that unites with rebirth would not occur without a support, and it is not possible for mind and its activities to be the support of mind.

Moreover, what is the reason that mind and its activities at that time are only the cause of the birth of a different kind of consciousness and cannot attract and produce a similar kind of mind and its activities?

Since one cannot have consciousness not supported by form for a time without having abandoned craving for form, form in the intermediate state definitely can be a condition that attracts and continues at the time of rebirth, and form that occurs with mind.
How can consciousness alone be born at this time?

If you say that at this time form is produced but you only speak of consciousness, then at this time there must be mind and its activities but you only speak of mind.ğŸ”½Therefore you should not say that
Therefore, one should not say this again:
In the middle, name-and-form ceases, and only consciousness arises. Only then can it give rise to name-and-form.

Moreover, this consciousness alone cannot be the intermediate existence giving rise to the existence at birth, because the intermediate existence has already ceased and the existence at birth has not yet arisen.
The state of the cessation of the intermediate existence and the non-arising of the existence at birth is not the existence at birth, so their statement comes from their own wrong attachment.
Moreover, how do you conceive of the arising of mind and mental factors in succession?
When feeling, etc. born from eye contact arise immediately after eye consciousness, do they arise simultaneously with other consciousnesses or alone?

If feeling, etc. arise simultaneously with other consciousnesses, does the arising of mental consciousness immediately take those objects as its object or does another consciousness arise taking a different object?

First, mental consciousness does not immediately take those objects as its object, because feeling, etc. born from eye contact depend on the eye faculty, and the objects of this mental consciousness are different from those of the eye faculty.

The feeling, etc., born from the eye faculty cannot have the past as its object, nor can the feeling, etc., born from eye contact have the mental faculty and dharmas as its conditions, because it is said that mental consciousness, etc., are born from the mental faculty and dharmas as conditions.
If it is born from the mental faculty and dharmas as conditions, it cannot be said to be born from eye contact, nor can it be said that another consciousness arises from another object.
If it can be born simultaneously because the object is different, then one would obtain all objects at one time.

If feeling, etc., are born alone without consciousness, then the subsequent consciousness would have no support. The stream of mental consciousness would be cut off and then would be born again. This is never the case in the lower realms, because they do not admit it.
Because they admit that in entering samÄdhi of cessation, etc., the stream of consciousness is born without interruption.

Therefore, their claim that the subsequent mind of the intermediate state is called name-and-form, and that consciousness is born alone without interval, and that only then does it give rise to name-and-form, is mere empty words, because it contradicts reason and the teachings.
The elder [Vasubandhu] hypothetically raises an objection here, saying:
The sÅ«tra should not say that consciousness conditions name-and-form, because they are only produced by the power of mutual dependence.
He then explains himself, saying:
This objection is unreasonable, because there is a distinction in terms of the conditions for birth and abiding.
That is to say, consciousness can be the condition for the birth of name-and-form, because consciousness enters the womb and causes it to be born.

After that birth, it becomes the support for the abiding of consciousness, and they mutually become conditions and are able to abide. Therefore, it is also said that consciousness is the condition for name-and-form.

This is also unreasonable, because it contradicts both principle and the teachings. That is to say, before the Buddha attained great enlightenment, he sought the conditions for the birth of consciousness and knew that it was name-and-form.
As a sÅ«tra says:

The Bodhisattva sought the conditions for the birth of old age and death, up to name-and-form, and knew that birth up to consciousness are the conditions in sequence. He sought the conditions for the birth of consciousness and knew that it was name-and-form.
If name-and-form were not the condition for the birth of consciousness, the knowledge of the Bodhisattva would be mistaken.

Also, they say that after birth, the six sense bases are the support for consciousness, and they are mutually conditioned and can be established. Therefore, they also say that consciousness is conditioned by name-and-form.

Some say that this is unreasonable. The consciousness they say is conditioned by name-and-form is the consciousness that is conditioned by name-and-form. How can it be the support for consciousness later?
Also, that sÅ«tra only says that consciousness depends on name-and-form to abide. Therefore, a sÅ«tra says, addressing Ä€nanda:

Also, you do not allow that consciousness and name-and-form are born together. How can you say that they mutually condition each other and abide?
Also, as explained above, the theory that denies the past and future is refuted, because sometimes one exists and sometimes the other does not exist.

How can the non-existent and the existent, or the existent and the non-existent, have the meaning of mutually supporting each other? Only the existent and the existent can have the meaning of mutually supporting each other.
How can the two be said to be mutually dependent?
Because if either is missing, neither can occur.

Also, in the Sutra of Great Emptiness, the Buddha did not explain the twelve members of dependent arising as a sequential cause and effect, nor did he only speak of the twelve members of dependent arising, because that sutra takes name-and-form as the condition for contact.
And because it speaks of seeking and so forth as the conditions for obtaining and so forth.

However, the Buddha, for Ananda, revealed the profound principle of dependent arising in that sutra, therefore the meaning of that sutra, in terms of the supporting conditions, only speaks of consciousness abiding in name-and-form, and that mental consciousness can only be established with the manas as its support and dharmas as its object.
The five consciousnesses such as the eye consciousness are established with the eye faculty and so forth as their support and form and so forth as their objects.
In this way, mental consciousness has only one support, but its objects are of two kinds. The five consciousnesses are the opposite of this.
Only the sixth consciousness is not so, because its support is always different from it. The remaining supports and objects may or may not exist simultaneously. This is the general principle.
We conclude that the theory of the Sthavira that name-and-form and the six sense bases are conditions for each other is not reasonable.
However, a scripture says,
When I contemplate conditioned arising, my mind turns back at consciousness. Beyond this, it does not go out again.
What is the meaning of this passage?

At that time, the Bodhisattva was contemplating the arising of the various members of conditioned arising from their respective causes. He first contemplated the separate causes for the arising of the first nine members. Finally, he contemplated consciousness and found that it had no separate cause for its arising, and therefore his mind turned back at consciousness and did not go out again.

However, the consciousness that appropriates a new birth has two causes for its arising: one is the prior member of prior birth, and the second is the simultaneous member. The meaning of the members of consciousness, action, and existence is not separate.

First contemplate the member of birth. The condition for birth is called existence. This is the same as the previously contemplated condition of karmic forces that are the prior condition for birth. Now contemplate name-and-form as the co-arisen condition. Therefore, when the mind returns to consciousness, it does not turn back, because the two conditions for the birth of consciousness have already been fully contemplated.

Because it is seen that in the present world, the consciousness of the stage of rebirth is born from the power of the two conditions that arose together in the past, it is understood that the other members are also like this, each arising in a moment and each possessing two conditions. Therefore, the two conditions are only fully revealed in the member of consciousness.
How is name-and-form a condition for consciousness that arises together?
Because consciousness abides and clings to it.
As a scripture says: Consciousness abides, except for consciousness, the rest is name-and-form.
Previously, abiding and clinging was explained as the meaning of consciousness abiding. Therefore a scripture says:
The joy and love that moisten consciousness cause it to increase and expand within the aggregates.

Does consciousness not depend on name-and-form to abide?

... and so on at length.

This is said because the consciousness abides and is attached to the name-and-form that arises together with it. It shows that consciousness is the condition for the arising of name-and-form, and therefore it is said that there are four abodes of consciousness.
Therefore, when the Bodhisattva reaches consciousness, he returns.

Although the links of old age and death are called name-and-form, etc., the previous contemplation of old age and death takes birth as a condition, which has already shown that the link of consciousness is the condition for the arising of name-and-form. However, not all old age and death have consciousness as a condition. In order to determine that only the arising of name-and-form has consciousness as a condition, he again contemplates name-and-form taking consciousness as a condition.

Having explained the name, we should now explain contact.
A verse says:
Contact arises from the union of the six, three, and one.
The treatise says:
There are six kinds of contact, namely eye contact up to mind contact.
What is this again?
It arises from the union of the three, namely faculty, object, and consciousness. Because of the union of these three, a separate contact arises.
Although the sixth [mind] and the three [faculty, object, and consciousness] belong to different time periods, they are related as cause and effect, so the meaning of union is established.

Or the meaning of union is that they have the same effect. Although faculty, object, and consciousness may not necessarily arise together, since the effect of contact is the same, they are called united.
The substance of contact is already established as a separate great ground.
Although it arises from the union of the three, it definitely arises together with consciousness, because it is said to arise from two conditions like consciousness.
That is to say, a scripture says:
Internally there is the body with consciousness, and externally there are name-and-form. The two pairs serve as conditions for the arising of various contacts, and so on at length.
Isn't it that this just says contact arises from the union of the three?

That is, the internal consciousness body refers to the six sense organs and six consciousnesses, and the external name-and-form refers to the six sense objects. Therefore, the two conditions are not established as the ultimate cause.
The meaning of the sutra is not so. The Buddha spoke of two.
That is, this sutra says that the two are the conditions for the arising of various contacts, not three.
Observing the meaning of this sutra, the words consciousness body indicate the six internal sense bases, and the words external name-and-form indicate the six external sense bases.
Other sutras also say that the two conditions give rise to. Therefore, the verse says:
The two of eye and form, and so on.
As previously explained.
Moreover, the sutra says that consciousness and contact are called name-and-form as conditions.
Since the conditions for arising are the same, how can there be a temporal sequence?
When the conditions are complete, they must arise, because there is nothing that can obstruct them.

Based on this, it is proven that such dharmas as feeling, which arise from contact through the eye, etc., arise together with the eye consciousness, because the cause of their arising is the same as that of the eye consciousness, etc.
Based on this, the sutra says:
Feeling, conceptualization, volition, and consciousness are mixed together and not separate.

If you hold that contact is a provisional entity, you should also admit that feeling, etc., arise simultaneously with contact, because this sÅ«tra says that consciousness is mixed with feeling, etc., and because consciousness is a part of contact.
Since there is no consciousness that is not mixed with feeling, etc., it is proven that feeling, etc., are universal mental activities.
They say:
The meaning of universal mental activities does not necessarily refer to those that are associated with all minds.
If that is so, what is the meaning of universal mental activities?

There are three kinds of universal mental activities: those associated with initial and sustained thought, those associated with joy, etc., those associated with the wholesome, etc., and those associated with the learner, etc. A dharma is called universal if it is present in all of these states. The others are not.
This is mere verbiage, because it contradicts the previous sÅ«tra.ğŸ”½They say:
You should examine the previous sÅ«tra carefully.
That sÅ«tra also says:

We are not yet clear whether this is in terms of objects or in terms of moments.
What is not yet clear about this explanation?
The former is in terms of moments, and the latter is in terms of objects. This principle is certain.
How do we know it is certain?
Because in other sÅ«tras, it is said that dharmas that arise together are mixed.
As a sÅ«tra says:

Here, it is not said in terms of non-simultaneous arising or in terms of objects, because the three necessarily arise together and the other two have no objects.
Therefore, the statement that feelings, etc. are mixed is definitely in terms of moments. Apart from this, it is not established.
If it is said that dharmas that arise immediately after one another are called mixed, then one not existing and one existing, the mixture is not established, as has already been explained.
It also cannot be said that having the same object is called mixed, lest there be the meaning of mixture between mental consciousness and eye consciousness, etc.
Therefore, when consciousness arises in regard to a single object, there must be the dharmas of contact, feeling, etc., that arise simultaneously with it.

There is definitely no consciousness that arises apart from contact, etc., because the sÅ«tras that have been cited have already been well established. How is it that the two dharmas of contact and feeling arise simultaneously, yet it is said that contact is the condition for feeling, but feeling is not the condition for contact?
Therefore a sÅ«tra says:
There is no diversity of feeling that has contact as a condition, but there is diversity of contact that has feeling as a condition.

Also, a sÅ«tra only says that eye contact as a condition generates feeling born of eye contact, and there has never been a sÅ«tra that says eye feeling as a condition generates contact born of eye feeling.

Isnâ€™t it seen in the present that although light and shadow born of a sprout arise simultaneously, only light and shadow are born from the sprout, and not the other way around? Contact and feeling are also like this.

This example is not the same, because there is no fixed cause to prove that although contact and feeling arise simultaneously, contact is the condition for feeling, but feeling is not the condition for contact, even though there is no present evidence. Although there is no present evidence, the principle is certain, because feeling must follow contact and have distinctions.
If one still does not understand, one should further open and reveal it by means of a different approach to make the meaning easy to understand.
There are two kinds of contact: one is nominal, the other real.
As for the nominal, it refers to the contact of the three, as a scripture says:
These three dharmas coming together and uniting are called contact.
As for the real, it refers to the mental contact, as a scripture says:
From the two conditions of eye and form, eye contact arises, and so on at length.
Also, a scripture says:
Internally there is the body with consciousness, and externally there are names and forms. From the two pairs of conditions, the arising of contact occurs.
Also, a scripture says:
Name and form are the conditions for contact, and the six sense bases are the conditions for contact.

In these and other innumerable scriptures, contact is nominally established as a condition for the arising of feeling, not as a condition for feeling, because feeling arises from the union of the three dharmas of faculty, object, and consciousness,
and not only from eye consciousness. This is because all mental activities are manifested by their supports.

Although consciousness is the dominant cause in the state of rebirth, it is said that feeling is also caused by the eye, form, and so on. Therefore, it is said that feeling born of the eye contact is born with the eye contact as its condition.

There is never a statement that feeling is the condition for contact, and contact is the condition for feeling. In this case, contact is a mental activity, and it can be said that it is the condition for feeling, and feeling is the condition for contact.
Therefore, the two scriptures are not contradictory.

Moreover, there is no contradiction in saying that they are also not contradictory in terms of a different meaning, namely, that feeling is born from contact through this door, but contact is not born from feeling through this door.
As a scripture says:
I do not see a single dharma that cuts off craving like the cultivation of mindfulness of the body.
This is based on a different meaning and denies other dharmas, but it is not based on all the methods of antidotes, because it is said later:
Like the cultivation of mindfulness of the body, mindfulness of breathing, mindfulness of the Buddha, the thought of death, and so on are also like this.
The phrase like this shows the meaning of a different meaning.
How do we know that feeling is also a condition for contact?
Other scriptures say that feeling has contact as its condition.
As a scripture says:
Because the body feels contact.
This shows that contact exists, and that feeling arises with contact as its condition.
Why are the eye, etc., also conditions for feeling, etc.? But it is said that contact is based on them, not that feeling, etc., are based on them.
Because the meaning of contact is evident in the combination, they are said to be in contact when they combine, but they are not said to be in contact with themselves.

Also, the eye, etc., are not the cause of the arising of contact, so it is said that contact is based on them. Why is it objected that
since they are also the cause of feeling, etc., feeling, etc., should be said to be based on them?
If this must be so, then it must be admitted that everything produced by the cause of contact is called contact.

However, in fact, among all dharmas that are results of contact, names are established in accordance with specific conceptualization for the most part. Consequently, it is well explained in other places that all mental activities are aroused by contact.

In the stage subsequent to contact, feeling is the strongest, and therefore the scriptures speak in general of all conditioned forces in terms of feeling.
However, the cause of feeling as explained in the doctrine of conditioned arising only takes real contact, not the hypothetical union of the three.
Why is this?
Because it is said to be the support.

That is, only real contact is revealed in terms of its support. Hypothetical existences cannot be found in the support, either in terms of superiority or inferiority, because if one of the three is missing, the other two cannot exist.
Consequently, we know that the scripture here speaks of real contact as the condition of feeling.

The meaning of dependent origination as explained here is that whatever state and whatever dharma is strong is said to be a condition, and the superior dharma that arises in the subsequent state is taken as the effect. Therefore there is no error.

Or, the great mass of future defilement takes feeling as its proximate cause. Therefore, in dependent origination, contact is said to be the condition for the arising of feeling. In order to avoid conditions, feeling does not manifest, and its root is severed.
All mental activities have the six sense bases as their condition. Why is it only said that the six sense bases are the condition for contact?
Because contact is superior in this state, it is called contact.
In reality, it should be known that all mental activities have the six sense bases as their condition.

For what reason, in reality, is contact superior, and it is only said that it is the condition for the superior feeling, and it is not said that it is the condition for the arising of the superior conceptualization, etc.?

It is just like the case of resolve, which is biased towards determination, lightness, comfort, and diligence, etc., which are in accord with calming and insight. The principle is naturally so, and one should not raise difficulties.
Name-and-form and the six sense bases, what is the difference in their conditions for contact?

What meaning does this sÅ«tra intend to explain?

The above sutra text discusses only hypothetical contact. In order to discuss the real contact that arises from these conditions, it further states:

The meaning of this is: If all kinds of hypothetical contact did not exist, then the mind would be in contact with difficulty in understanding its own name during the three periods of time, because its substance would not arise and could not be known. If one analyzes the meaning of the sutra in this way, the contact that has name-and-form as its condition is precisely the two kinds of contact.

Although the six sense bases as a condition for contact is also definite in a certain stage, it is shown in terms of sentient beings' support. Name-and-form as a condition for contact is shown in terms of both support and object, so there is a difference.
There is another meaning. Here, the group of names is called name-contact. It is the meaning of taking names as the support. This takes the sixth consciousness as its support.
Here, the group of forms is called form-contact. It is the meaning of taking forms as the support. This takes the five sense organs as its support.
Because of this, the power of the support of various contacts is used to distinguish their names, such as eye-contact, up to mind-contact. The sixth consciousness and mind are one meaning.

If the six contacts that are the support of all kinds of name-and-form do not exist, then there definitely will not be any other contact without a support that can be known. Since there is nothing that can be known, it also cannot be established.
The meaning of this is that apart from the six supports, etc., there is no separate false contact, and apart from the six kinds of contact, there is also no real contact.

Here it is shown that name-and-form is a distinction of the six sense bases, in order to explain the various meanings of dependent origination, and to enable Ananda to understand the profound meaning.

It is said that visual consciousness only perceives blue and does not perceive it is blue, while mental consciousness perceives blue and also perceives it is blue, and so on at length.
Therefore, contact associated with resistance is named from the supported object, while contact associated with ideation is named from the long object.
Some say:
Mental consciousness is called ideation because it is dominant in the production of speech.
Some say:

Contact associated with resistance is named from the supported object, while contact associated with ideation is named from the dominant associated object.
These are the first six contacts, which, according to their specific corresponding states, are further divided into eight kinds.
A verse says:
Illuminating, non-illuminating, neither, pure, defiled, the rest,
Corresponding to the two characteristics of craving and anger, pleasure, etc., accord with the three feelings.
The treatise says:

Contacts corresponding to illuminating, non-illuminating, etc. are divided into three: first, illuminating contact; second, non-illuminating contact; third, neither illuminating nor non-illuminating contact.

The rest refers to the pure and the rest of the defiled, namely, contaminated wholesome and indeterminate.

One part of non-illuminating contact arises frequently. Based on that, the two contacts of craving and anger are further established, because they correspond to the latent tendencies of craving and anger.

All are comprehensively included and become three contacts: first, contact that accords with pleasant feeling; second, contact that accords with painful feeling; third, contact that accords with neither painful nor pleasant feeling.
What is contact that accords with feeling?

A verse says:

Among the six, the first five are called bodily feeling because they depend on material faculties.
Feeling born from contact with the mind is called mental feeling because it only depends on the mind.
A verse says:

The treatise says:
Within the previously mentioned single feeling of mind, due to the differences in mental activities, it is further divided into eighteen.

Because the three feelings are only associated with the mind, and the six objects are different, they become eighteen.
It is not that a single feeling-tone is associated with the mental consciousness, and the different objects become six, because the feelings are different.

Because that sutra says when the eye sees forms and so on in detail, the practice of joy in the mental faculty is induced by the five consciousnesses and associated with mental consciousness. This should not be disputed.

Because the practices of the mental faculty are only based on mental consciousness, they are called near;
